0zbdj66Gj7UjiYRV-Ex_Eg.text: Had dinner at No Signboard Restaurant Geylang on 3 July 2015. The meal for 3 was expensive at $50 per person but food was below average. Had a nicer experience at the same place last Oct 2014. Last night ordered 3 dishes comprising a small white pepper crab (not enough pepper), small steamed fish (bland and meat a bit tough); and large $20 hor fun ( that came with 3 small prawns, some slices of toman fish, chye sin and few slices of chicken - no egg). Not sure if the standard of food is better at the other branches. Generally, the quantity & quality of food is not worth the prices charged.

LFLbTVwkLdE7SWsHaC_91Q.text: Decent food. Better service than Jumbo but this does feel more like a hawker center. They told us they didn't have Heineken but they do.

OUjFh81-zHkL5MEWuzBwNg.text: This is a cool spot to eat seafood.  It's super busy though. We didn't wait to long for a table.   It's expensive of course,  but it's Singapore.  The seafood is good. It could be cleaner.  Wish it was closer to the train.

4IYs3_swdOYLehEqU7Hbvw.text: Outstanding chili crab, but I think it may be a tad overpriced.  The 2 chili crabs I had in Singapore were at Newton Circus Food Centre and this place.  This place was much better, although it was NOT cheap by any means.  The neighbourhood is Singapore's red light district and is as close to dodgy as Singapore gets, but the crab was cooked to perfection and the sauce was phenomenal.  It does take long to prepare but worth the wait.

5jtqbRW850EnR-_5NurPyQ.text: White pepper crab was really good. The venison did not taste like venison... Instead like cat or some other myaterious animal... not like beef either... Not sure what they served us in place of venison there...Scallops were great, and a beef noodle dish was good as well.Very nice location to walk over to the water to see the light show :)

X8Rrbqf26yOC6F4FZJr1KA.text: Is it normal to charge for peanuts and wet naps that are already on the table? White pepper crab was okay. Fried rice was really good but this pricey dinner was NOT worth the money..

mjEIJx47BjDE1SPYejvHJw.text: Can't really go wrong with No Signboard. They deliver each time. The Geylang restaurant is supposed to be their best. I'm not sure I noticed any difference in regards to the food. Had delicious chilli crab (and the customary fried buns), a clam and vermicelli dish which was absolutely divine, some greens and a yummy sticky pork rib dish. Another one of my 'must go' places when I'm in Singapore.

NoZv7ZmrI1VrIsq8hBfw1g.text: I haven't really been a fan of No Singboard Seafood restaurant until I came here for a late Saturday night seafood supper. This is the only one of the No Signboard Seafood's I'll visit, ambience of sitting street side in geylang, adds to that charm that only fellow expats would understand and relate too.  The outdoor dining area is gritty and dirty, with cheap plastic chairs and wonky tables with large fans providing some airflow under the large canvas awning.  A trip to the bathroom will have you carefully stepping over the piping and puddles leading into the live seafood tanks, where they have everything from seabss, crabs, lobsters, frogs, prawns and many more. The chili and black pepper crab here is very good. One of the places I'll frequent when I'm craving one of the two. Would recommend this place particularly to anyone who wants to give overseas guest a uniquely Singaporean seafood experience.

LAMkM5KIw8RHcVz_XVlj0g.text: I think I'm just a sucker for Chili Crab. Their sauce is fantastic - people will argue forever about who's is best (Jumbo, Long beach, Melben, etc.). Fact is, they're all delicious. This is one of the spicier sauces I've had, but still not overbearingly spicy. Location feels more local than say Jumbo in CQ - Geylang is  tourist attraction in its own right...

H_wXB4ZwlZ8SDvJI4Ai25A.text: Chilli Crab! I miss this place so much, you can't go wrong with an establishment with no name. Simple; go for the crab, stay for Geylang (joke). Also wear the bib.

SY2oFIYOm0szPgYNOAg6nA.text: Singaporean chili crab and black pepper crab.  Come with at least four people so you can order more dishes.  I've been told by friends that the level of spiciness can vary at this place and that we went on a high spicy night.  It was definitely packing heat but bearable nonetheless.  Everything else we got here was delicious including the morning glory, the cereal prawns, the Chinese New Year salad, the deep fried bread.  That deep fried bread is a must get side if you're ordering the chili crab because you can dip it in the sauce.  You could do that with rice too but then that would feel too healthy.They do charge for all the extras here including water, wet wipes, etc.  Trust me, you'll need all those.  While I have been told that there are many good chili crab restaurants in Singapore, you can't beat the outdoor ambiance here.  It's not as raw as a hole-in-wall but it's so nice eating in the cool, warm breeze.

photos.caption: Photo of No Signboard Seafood Restaurant - Singapore, Singapore. Lunar new year salad (before)
Photo of No Signboard Seafood Restaurant - Singapore, Singapore. Lunar new year salad (after)
Photo of No Signboard Seafood Restaurant - Singapore, Singapore. Chili crab

93BOR1fmwuADeyPRYvKlZQ.text: Excellent chilli-crab here - I prefer this over Jumbo. The sauce is spicy and flavorful, leaving you with a slight numbness (essence of mala). I'm a big fan of the mantou they serve as well.The dining area is outside with no AC so prepare to sweat.

photos.caption: Photo of No Signboard Seafood Restaurant - Singapore, Singapore

HhY6iW8eYZeskJinlLHdFw.text: Since it's the only restaurant I ate at in Singapore during my layover, it is the best restaurant I have eaten in Singapore!  The food is so tasty. Fish is fresh. Crab is fresh. Veggies is fresh. And they all taste differently with very different sauce. The atmosphere is like a street restaurant with a canopy cover.  The place is not too clean but all the fishes look lively and healthy in their tanks. Restroom is not so clean. The place is huge and amazingly fills up!

O29hkKHEUF1TxwCQ-9bvyw.text: No Signboard - A place loved by its patrons so much they gave it a name.Before I get into this too much I have to say I had never had Singapore Chilli Crab until this night. I know about the other alternatives and do plan to test them out but for now it was No Signboard.I found this seafood restaurant very accessible via public transport (get off on the Aljunied stop on the Green East West MRT line and its a short walk from there). Me and some work mates thought we would get our Chilli Crab on and swanned down here after work the other day.Rocking up around 7pm, there was still a few spare tables so we didn't have to wait - bonus! Chilli crab was always going to be on our menu so that was a given. We also had the Drunken Bull Frog and Sambai Kang Kong.With 4 beers on offer (Guiness, Tiger, Heineken and Carlsberg) we opted for the Tiger which goes for $8 for the bigger bottles. The crab is priced at $60 a kilo and then you just decide which way you want it cooked and go from there. We generally went for around half a kilo of crab each because we were trying other options from the menu.The Chilli Crab? AMAZING! Then again it is my only benchmark, but for now I am thoroughly impressed. The Drunken Bull Frog was a close second for me but maybe that is because I miss frog (we don't really have that in Australia).Its all very out in the open and as other people have said, I would probably avoid this place on a really hot and steamy day. But as it was the other night (a bit cooler) I found it quite pleasant. Bring napkins or wet wipes too as they don't provide them free of charge. Chilli crab can get quite messy so bear this in mind when deciding what to wear there as well! All in all I walked away thoroughly impressed and plan to return in future to sample the White Pepper Crab which I hear is something of a specialty here also.

photos.caption: Photo of No Signboard Seafood Restaurant - Singapore, Singapore. For when you have paid your bill I think.
Photo of No Signboard Seafood Restaurant - Singapore, Singapore. The Famous Chilli Crab with buns and Sambai Kang Kong
Photo of No Signboard Seafood Restaurant - Singapore, Singapore. Drunken Bull Frog.

JhIvQJ_cjsrhwFzhvUfQ0w.text: Well,  this was a huge disappointment especially for the price you pay. Referring to the Chili Crab - the reason why I came here.  Reviews seemed OK, an Australian friend recommended it - but I did see some reviews about quality and taste being down from its glory days.  Th Uber driver taking me there also implied it is not the same since the original chef moved on. But I had to see and judge for myself.  Now I know.  I specifically asked for SPICY chili crab and what I got was a tasteless dish with hardly any flavor or character to it.  Did not even finish it - eating for the sake of eating with no joy is pointless.  It is not cheap - my total bill was S$110 of which $65 was for chili crab.  It was wasted money and it hurts a bit since it was not even average.  What burns you more is that there is a nominal but silly charge for plain water in plastic cup and a towel to clean ur hands - mind you, we are talking crabs here. My advise, try some other restaurants known for their chili crab and avoid this - at least for now.

photos.caption: Photo of No Signboard Seafood Restaurant - Singapore, Singapore

l6rv4Osv9HJqdwThgJZwaw.text: The quest for all things delicious in Singapore continued during my family's recent visit.  My aunt took one of those brochures for tourists at Changi and chili crab was named one of the top 10 must-try's and off we head to Geylang for our chilli crab as I have been told that No Signboard serves the best chilli crab in town.  To be honest I didn't have much expectations because 1. I am not a fan of chilli crabs I prefer black pepper crab; 2. I tried No Signboard in Hong Kong a few years ago and it was grossly overpriced with small portions; 3.  prior experiences with other famous and tourists oriented joints like Long Beach and Jumbo left the same impression that these famous crab places are rip-offs.  I am so wrong!  The chilli crab is amazing! and I don't even like chilli crab in the first place.  We ended up ordering extra servings of the little fried buns so we can scoop up the very last drop of sauce.  The other chilli crabs I have tasted so far all just tasted like spicy ketchup to me but the No Signboard version is different - just the right blend of spicyness and sweetness.  Oh and we ordered the white pepper crab since I have only had the black pepper version before and it is also yummy!  And oh the size of the crab, which is important, we ordered the smallest sized crab and the meat is very fresh and dense.We also had the stir fried sotong with pepper and chilli, a baby kailan, half an butter chicken and a bitter gourd soup.  The price is not cheap but hey, compared with all the other crab places around town I found it very reasonable.  It comes down to about SGD50 each for the 4 of us and we are stuffed to the brim.  Last time we spent about the same at Jumbo and had to order McDonalds later in the night.  So farewell Jumbo and Long Beach.  The outdoor seatings are spacious and comfortable and I think it's a great place to take visitors to since you can take a stroll around Geylang before or after dinner. This is probably the one non-sterile place in Singapore and shows that this place offers more than just glass and steel buildings or HDB blocks.  We also had durian a bit further down Geylang road - a very sweet ending to our night out in Geylang.

photos.caption: Photo of No Signboard Seafood Restaurant - Singapore, Singapore

PFzK6YpDR2dmAmg8P35WCg.text: Go here for the Chili and pepper Crab.  It was great as I was told it would be.  Service was good as well.  Just watch for the up sell to the more expensive king crab.  It is twice the price, and as I was told not worth it.  Had great side dishes as well.Overall good experience.  We will be back.

8W28zDPgmyiHh3xXDdDQaA.text: Yummy food but it never comes out at once. Finished 2 plates before our butter prawns arrived. Feel very rushed with waitress hovering behind us and asking if we are ready to order every 3 minutes right at the start.

photos.caption: Photo of No Signboard Seafood Restaurant - Singapore, Singapore. Al fresco dining

qNMZy3D5Aevyz-pP4kwdZA.text: it was the first time we have ever tried salty egg as a sauce - BOY where have we been? we are missing out and you are too if you've never had it! the spicy crab was underwhelming - the sauce isn't something i really enjoyed but we tried it just to try it. We were in Singapore for about 3 days and didn't try spicy crab til the last day so we have nothing to compare it to. we had spicy crab, shrimps, veggies, and rice. delicious meal to complete our time here. We also came pretty late so there was no wait for tables. the area is pretty local and out in the boonies or i've been told is the red light district? Tip- bring LOTS of tissues and wipes perhaps. Bring your own drinks! sneakily maybe? lol

photos.caption: Photo of No Signboard Seafood Restaurant - Singapore, Singapore. Spicy veggies with squid?
Photo of No Signboard Seafood Restaurant - Singapore, Singapore. Spicy/chili crab
Photo of No Signboard Seafood Restaurant - Singapore, Singapore. salted egg shrimps! i literally ate all the sauce with rice! and bread!

L-vbEYaGBR3F-vcJhLyIqQ.text: First ever Chilli Crab experience. The highlights:Fingers so messy that napkins were no longer useful. Garden hose anywhere?Never ending Tiger beers. Cold and hit the spot.So much crab... so much chilliKinda pricey for all that sauce, but an experience one should have at least in a lifetime.

photos.caption: Photo of No Signboard Seafood Restaurant - Singapore, Singapore. Chilli Crab and beers. Mmmmmm
Photo of No Signboard Seafood Restaurant - Singapore, Singapore

amC-9B9TSV11itPEJm9prA.text: I don't know how I could've forgotten about this place, this was my break-virgin into Singapore-style crab on my very first trip to Singapore 2 years ago, and then my local friends took me to the tourist, nicer one at Vivocity b/c they know I'm a roller.  Just kidding lol.This is what real street food eating really is: no decor but just eating it out with no care, all reckless abandon; you're not worrying over your clothes or ppl staring lol.  Because everyone's eating like a pig and smacking their fingers dry.So they ordered 2 of the most popular ones: the black pepper (which looks muddy) and sweet chili, which really is more of a tomato/ketchup-like with a bit of a kick.  I honestly had a hard time deciding which is the best, as I went back and forth.  And guess what, I still have a hard time deciding lol.This place is way out there in the burbs but in Singapore, that's just a 15-min drive across the country lol, correct?

QSDQ4qKMS63pKw8Fnh2izA.text: What we ordered? White Pepper crab, steamed veggies, and chili prawnsAll the food was tasty but very overpriced. Would I come back? Won't go out of my way to come here.

Ci12QoUIk6ZLjElioPEQmg.text: We were just walking around the Red Light District when we came across No Signboard, and we were very excited because we had read quite a bit about how great the seafood is!  So we just had to give it a try even though our bellies were already full.Service:  Slow when it comes to getting the check, and it was difficult to understand some of the waitresses (their English, at least).  But the Tiger beer lady was nice.Ambience: we were seated near the edge of the restaurant (which is outdoors), and the area is infested with mosquitoes (at least if you are prone to mosquito bites). We asked to be seated elsewhere, but they told us there were no other tables available (even when people left they wouldn't move us).  And there were some creepy men and prostitutes who kept eyeing us when they walked by.  Otherwise, it's a very lively place!Food:  We didn't order chili crab because we just had it the other day, but it looked quite delicious when the table next to us got it!  But the sauce looked pretty soupy.  In any case, we got razor clams, which were SOOOOO fresh, and the king prawns were deliciously juicy (until I took a bite of my last one, which was super dry).  I do think they had some consistency problems within some of the dishes.  Aside from the king prawns, the claypot tofu had shrimp also, but one of them tasted old and fishy while another had a fresh taste to it...  And def don't order the deer.  When it was good, the food was delicious, but when it's bad, it's so bad you have to spit it out.

UcSVMpuUwsyoEaWvPL5NQw.text: I had a great first time experience here, due to a variety of factors:1) It had just rained earlier in the day, and when we arrived (late afternoon) the weather was PERFECT for al fresco dining. 2) My husband and I came here really early on Saturday (5 PM) so there was no wait and the staff was very attentive.3) I only ate a cheese stick, some cashews, and a small strawberry cake throughout the day, so by the time I arrived I was ready to chow down on some REAL food!As much as I really wanted to try the chili crab, a few friends + Yelp mentioned that it was a lot spicier than Jumbo's. My husband can't handle too much spice, and it was just the two of us, so we chose the next most talked about dish- white pepper crab! We also ordered drunken shrimp and fried rice. The drunken shrimp was served to us in big bowls filled to the brim with soup, and I enjoyed it very much. The fried rice, however, was probably the best fried rice I've ever tasted in my life. There was a little bit of everything in there, and it was absolutely divine. We also loved how they served it as our first dish, as we prefer to eat the rice with our crab. As for our white pepper crab, it didn't disappoint! It was served with a really flavorful sauce and some veggies that complimented the crab perfectly. It wasn't spicy, but at the same time it had taste, which made both me and my husband happy campers!No bibs were given to us (were we supposed to ask for them?), but they did have small IKEA laundry baskets at each table where you can keep your purse and any outerwear that you don't want to stain. Make sure to bring tissues if one wet nap isn't enough for you! Also, they do have a VIP section, which I presume means air conditioning. Not sure if there's anything special you need to do to get in, or if the prices are different!Speaking of prices, I did find it a bit pricey, as the bill for the two of us was $115 (however, this did include 1 large Tiger beer that we split and a dessert as well.) They do accept credit cards, though.Bottom line, I am a newly converted fan, and one of these days I will return and try the chili crab once and for all! Maybe I'll also bring a bottle of wine with me, as the corkage fee is only $10. Wanna come with? :)

OnRCNVILu9AHq-cc_MtXwQ.text: The chili crab was pricey, but delicious. As everybody else has posted already, there are no napkins. You're given a bowl of water with lemon to clean your fingers. If you're a sloppy eater like myself, then I recommend bringing some napkins of your own. They only have wet napkins for a small charge. The service is friendly and attentive.

jLjwiJvrgUXXFMGkK94S0Q.text: I love seafood, and I am fussy.Bamboo clams - $12 each and I've had better. The clams were a little over-cooked today and it could be less chewy. It is also under-seasoned and could do with more garlic.Cereal prawns and baby squids - both decent but again better versions elsewhere.Yang Zhou fried rice - beautifully fried.Chilli crab - I am definitely a bigger fan if pepper crab. But I was bringing visitors tonight and decided to go with our national dish. The dish is enjoyable and we went with the male crab (firmer flesh vs female crab with roe. Yes, sometimes, life is full of tough choices). Again, not the best out there. I kind of prefer long beach or jumbo.Add a vegetable and 4 large bottles of tiger beer, the bill came out to $200.What I like about the place is actually the location. Located in the colorful part of Singapore, you sit by Geylang road in the open and feel that this is how Singapore feels 20 years ago.

DUnCIN_i5cr5BNvULbCD2A.text: Wow, what an experience...My only other chilli crab experience has been at Long Beach at Dempsey and this was SO. MUCH. MORE. AWESOME. I was so gutted on our first experience when our crab was deconstructed by the waiter at the table (I had visions of bibs and crabby faces... granted, our Singaporean host thought we would prefer it the clean way). The grittiness of Geylang teemed with friendly service, amazing flavours, reasonable prices (crab $55 kilo apparently quite pricey though?) and some pretty blemmin good crab. We tried the kang kong, the oyster sauce kai lan, the chicken wings in prawn paste, the steamed bums, and the white pepper and chilli crab. Jury is still out on which one is better... Be warned, the chilli crab is pretty spicy for most ang mo palates, however it didn't stop our British guest getting amongst. Total bill $148 for four people including 3 large tiger beers. We left very full.. I will be back with more of our international visitors. Be prepared to get messy.

ajb7-QxVrUh2Pq0cV6p3pg.text: Chili crab:No Signboard sauce is way better than Jumbo's.Pepper crab:Both are decent.Service:No signboard all the way.Make sure to always order a side of fried rice to enjoy with the chili sauce, and bamboo clams as an appetizer! it's so delicious, juicy, and tender. I only ate bamboo clams as a Spanish Tapas and it's a total different experience. They also give you a smashed garlic sauce which is to die for. note: No signboard is mostly known for its white pepper crabs which I haven't tried yet. I subtracted one star for being so pricey for seafood, but it's like that across all popular seafood joints in Singapore, No signboard, Jumbo, and Long Beach. crab= $55/kgbamboo clams= $13 for onefried rice: cheap. $8~12 something unless you order the clam rice.

z_Z3s6sGE5G0tuqqsB9MsQ.text: I went to Jumbo Seafood and then tried No Signboard and I think I liked the food here better!  The sauce in the chilli crab was more richer while I thought Chilli tasted a bit like ketchup.  And it seemed like there were more locals here while Jumbo was definitely a touristy spot. Cons: no ac so we were dripping sweat.  They charge for nearly everything, including water and napkins which seemed ridiculous. Pros: the food was great. We ate chilli crab, green beans, and lots of fried bread.  One med sized crab was enough for 2 girls.  Very close to the MRT

aCpwOH8uvT3ISx9jD2auOw.text: The crabs are $50/kg which is supposedly pricier than the other restaurants. I'm really not sure what's the market rate. I just assumed they are not cheap. The usual flavors are available- White/Black Pepper, Chilli, Butter, Steamed, Ginger and Spring Onion, Cheese. Can't remember if they have Salted Egg Yolk, which has become one of my favorite flavors for crabs.The Black Pepper crab looks harmless enough but boy is it spicy! Really peppery flavor that turned on the faucet in my nose and had it running for a while. The restaurant gave us the male crab for this dish. I love the kick of the pepper in this dish. You gotta eat this fast because it turns cold due to the lack of a gravy to keep it heated. Apparently the white pepper crab was the original signature dish of NS but now people associate them with Chili crabs. Shall try that another time.NS used to hold the standard for Chili crabs in Singapore (according to this skinnyfat girl that is). Every other chili crab is either too tomato-ish, too diluted, too spicy or too ________(insert something negative here) as compared to NS. I'm sad to say that the standard has indeed fallen. I thought the gravy is watered down a little. It kinda lacks that oomph and punch that it used to possess. While the meat of the crab is succulent as before, the crabs are really pretty puny these days. The image of those HUGE Sri Lankan crab pincers from eons ago is still etched in my memory and the size of the current ones are really disappointing.

w9Cx-xESFVidA9dyS__CsA.text: Good place to have chili crabs. Second only to the other famous crab eating place at the East Coast Rd. Love the balanced taste of the chili sauce. We ordered crabs and 3 other veggies and tofu dishes. Just realized that this place also serves crocodile and deer meat dishes. This place also offers fresh durian, a bit more expensive than other places. Actually this place is $$$$

photos.caption: Photo of No Signboard Seafood Restaurant - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of No Signboard Seafood Restaurant - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of No Signboard Seafood Restaurant - Singapore, Singapore

w6ET_wevvwlP54p37bsTXA.text: Found this place on a list of best chili crab places in Singapore and although the chili crab didn't disappoint, everything else did. Seating is pretty much outdoors with a cover. It's a huuuge restaurant with a bunch of tourists.DO NOT GET A SET MENU. DON'T DO IT. JUST GET THE CRAB!!! So as you can tell, my family got the set menu. It sucked. Came with some fried wontons, peppered crab, fried shrimp, and other forgettable items because they didn't taste good. At all.

photos.caption: Photo of No Signboard Seafood Restaurant - Singapore, Singapore. @elvianathio on Instagram
Photo of No Signboard Seafood Restaurant - Singapore, Singapore. Carrot bird! Via @elvianathio on Instagram
Photo of No Signboard Seafood Restaurant - Singapore, Singapore. Chili crab so good! Via @elvianathio on Instagram

Pqt5AiFt5n1cMtRnSJKHaQ.text: It has been years since we were here and I recall they do have a Chili Crab sauce that is rather different from the rest - better that is.  After picking up me boy from Mandai on route back to Marine Parade thought the logical path would be Geylang Branch.  Got to say service was extremely attentive and to the extend that it was a little a pushy as each staff tries hard to up-sell.  And yes even the paper apron cost $0.60/piece.  The saddest part was that the Chili Crab Sauce came in as a little reddish as oppose to somewhat orangy/brown?  The worst is that at S$112 (before the ++) the crab just was not fresh.  We basically ordered the same dishes as we did at Jumbo as a comparison and again both the Baby Kailan and Mee Goreng fell short.  If you are looking for ambiance this is not the place to be.  But seriously with this price best we head back to our fav - Jumbo East Coast where we NEVER EVER have a bad crab day in so many times we have been there through the years.

DKcJ9ToQn_j_jnJ2v29lsQ.text: This place is amazing!  In kind of a seedy area of Singapore but the have a basket to place your valuables in to evade the common pick pockets of the area.   The staff was excellent and very attentive to my needs.   I couldn't make up my mind between the chili crab or the white pepper crab and the waitress advised I go with both!   Lol.   I ordered the chili crab and the white pepper prawn, both were absolutely amazing!  Highly recommend if you are looking for a great meal.

R-Xd2-22ahnHP-TyZUV0Sg.text: White pepper crab $80/kg. Kind of pricey as Newport back in California you can feed a family of four for same price. The crab was pretty good. Reason for three stars is the service. Worst I've had in Singapore. Took forever to get our rice. Also I felt almost conned. If I hadn't read the reviews beforehand I wouldn't have known to not touch anything they put on the table. The waiters will put appetizers and wet wipes on the table without telling you it's not free. Thankfully we didn't eat anything so waiters took it away. They also try to upsell you on other entrees. Don't get suckered and just stick to the crab. Also their tea sucks. Costs $2 for Chinese tea and it was basically their version of a Lipton tea bag- bitter. Also they automatically charge 10% service to the bill, but service was the worst. Oh and other restaurants don't charge for service so that was not fun to find out.

I36GffZST4ohhboAcXjNpg.text: Sorry No Signboard, we really, really, really wanted to love you, but it just wasn't meant to be!  Blame it on all the local hawker centers.  Why does their food have to be SO CHEAP and SO GOOD?!?  We are forever ruined....Alas, I digress.... on to the review:Deep Fried Bullfrog Legs (5/5) - Our favorite thing here, oddly enough!  The meat was tender and plump, and the seasoning was spot on!  Kinda tasted like sweet MSG haha, and we ain't mad at that!  Does anyone know of a place in LA/SD/Orange County that serves this???  Please tell us!!!Chili Crab (2/5) - Of course we had to order this.  It's only advertised on every tourist marketing material in Singapore!  It's like going to the UK without trying the fish and chips (which I will forever regret!).  Well, lesson learned.  Or rather, not so much, as our mandatory quest for chili crab fell way short of expectations.  To put it bluntly, it was like crab slathered in  that tomato sardine sauce.  Oh, how I wish I were kidding.  Well.... "the more you know".... still glad to have given it a chance, albeit an expensive one.  White Pepper Crab (2/5) - I have a thing for white pepper, so I thought I would be all over this one, but really, this tasted of ONLY white pepper and corn starch!  It was too much for me.  Pass.Fried Bread Buns (2/5) - First of all, after order two crab dishes drenched it sauce, it would have been nice if the rolls had been complementary, but heck, for a place that charges for napkins and sauce, I get it.  The bread itself didn't have much flavor except for a hint of sweetness, and was dense and a bit dry in the middle.  We used the bread to dip into our sauce but as mentioned previously, I wasn't too big of a fan of those so it bit of a loss.  As we look back at our trip to Singapore, this restaurant was by far the most expensive, yet least enjoyable place we ate at.  Perhaps these flavors are more the acquired type, because we did not acquire to them very easily.  And yes, they will nickle and dime you for every little thing that they can.  Just be smart and bring your own waters and wet wipes, and don't eat anything extra you didn't order, including the peanuts and the side sauces.

photos.caption: Photo of No Signboard Seafood Restaurant - Singapore, Singapore. One day we will be back to give you another shot mr chili crab... But not here!!!

qOYCZ-_m2jzOx-umwSra4g.text: It's our first time in Singapore and we decided to try out seafood here since we heard Singapore is  famous for it.  My family decided to eat here thanks to reviews but it was super expensive for what you get.I am rating this place one star because our waiter, Ajao, got our order wrong.  We asked for butter but she gave us white pepper which was too spicy for me and I wasnt able to eat the 400$ crab.  My whole family knew I didn't ask for the spicy but we didn't realize until after they started eating it. Ajao did not want to correct her own mistake.  She told me that if I wanted to eat, I would need to buy another one.  We asked if we can exchange the one she got wrong but she kept saying to buy another crab.   I just ended up not eating. My family isn't rich but we wanted to have a treat, and unfortunately our experience just ended up sour.

bZRthgAlHymL1UHn3NWljg.text: White pepper crab is really good and the quality was great compared to other places. The crab meat was sweet and does not stick to the shell. I had been to other places where the sauce was good but the crab meat would stick to the shell. The razor clam was also very good.

2sJUy1rFICR2ooeTLcOP5w.text: There are two No signboard restaurants and one with open seating, the other is more upscale. Everyone told us to go to this open seating one. Dress casually as you are going to eat messy chili crab. Price is very reasonable and you get a lot!!  We got chili crab, fried rice, noodle dish and conch. Fried rice was quite good.  It wasn't crowded at around 7pm but around 8pm, it was packed. Service is attentive and fast. Highly recommended.

photos.caption: Photo of No Signboard Seafood Restaurant - Singapore, Singapore. Abalone Thai style
Photo of No Signboard Seafood Restaurant - Singapore, Singapore. Chili crab with fried buns

ebZwLIz-3PWKLWmKq_L9ig.text: It is guaranteed people would recommend you this place for Singapore's famous chili crab first time you are here. It happens to  too. So no doubt i have tried them numerous time till i find another place in Chinatown.It was so hard for me to love their chili crab, they use a lot of egg yolk and and spice wasn't right, just feel sick afterwards. White pepper crab with leak taste much better, it's tasty and a little spicy. So since then i didn't order any chili crab at any place till a friends' day out in chinatown sea food restaurant, there i found the best chili crab(see my review for Chinatown sea food restauran :)It is a good place to go while you near gaylang area, interesting people watching and culture, for that unique experience it is a must go places :)

fCf54N1oir15hPmkcmh1HA.text: The spicy crab is delicious and tasty. Come in the afternoon and before dinner because it is not crowded and you can sit in the air condition area. Enjoy the crab and don't care how ugly when you are fighting with the crab.

photos.caption: Photo of No Signboard Seafood Restaurant - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of No Signboard Seafood Restaurant - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of No Signboard Seafood Restaurant - Singapore, Singapore

lVnN8dL6fc97rWSvw5xH4Q.text: Finally tried this place after reading so many reviews pitting it against Jumbo.  Stuck to the basics and ordered curry powder Chilli crab, black bean bamboo clams, salted fish fried rice and a garlicky veggie.  The curry powder crab was a nice change from the oft too sweet chilli crab. It had a slightly spicy heat to it that left me wanting more.  The clams are just not my thing. I think the sauce was great though. Only reason it got 4 out of 5 was it took a really long time for the crab to come out. We had basically eaten everything else and were full! Overall, the location was nice, service was decent and their food was good. Would go back for sure.

photos.caption: Photo of No Signboard Seafood Restaurant - Singapore, Singapore. Bamboo clam
Photo of No Signboard Seafood Restaurant - Singapore, Singapore. Curry powder crab medium

xdggasTEPg2PSTTVkWRV5g.text: As a tourist, of course I had to come to No Signboard Seafood Restaurant.  Even before my trip, I looked up places on Yelp and TripAdvisor and knew I had to come here.  I didn't know there were other locations and I'm glad I had locals to suggest and take me around and Yelp reviews to read, because I'm glad I went to the original location here in Geylang.  Apparently the prices at the Geylang location are much more reasonable and they are less likely to jip you out of your hard earned cash here.Valet parking is available for $4.  No signboard has mostly outdoor seating under plenty of fans, but it also has an indoor area towards the back left corner.  At night though, it's not so bad outside (and I'm not a fan of Singapore weather at all).No Signboard isn't like your average food centers where a plate of food costs you $3-5.  It's actually quite expensive.  Like most established Singaporean restaurants, you can choose the size of your dishes here (S/M/L), but even the small sizes start at double digits.  Also, as with many other restaurants, they do not provide napkins here.  I've learned to bring wet wipes and napkins around with me everywhere I go now.Lime juice was okay - tastes like powdered lemonade from the states... not sure if it' anything worth trying.Food:1. Chili crab - must get, obviously.  The meat was tender and fresh.  The sauce was spicy for everyone, but not really spicy at all for me.  Everyone was sweating, but I was fine, so it depends on your spice tolerance.2. Salt/chili fried bullfrog - this was actually my favorite dish out of the bunch.  Perfectly battered and crispy outside that was salty and a little bit spicy.  SO GOOD3. Some 油条 cuttlefish thing - fried goodness4. Some sort of coconut-y fried prawn - no shells - delicious5. Eggplant - standard chinese eggplant dish, but you have to have your veggies!Anyway, make your way to the Geylang resty if you've got a chance.

photos.caption: Photo of No Signboard Seafood Restaurant - Singapore, Singapore. Chilli crab
Photo of No Signboard Seafood Restaurant - Singapore, Singapore. Eggplant
Photo of No Signboard Seafood Restaurant - Singapore, Singapore. Salt and pepper bullfrog

7S2OrqUxnsyb3TQjaff5WQ.text: 2nd crab I got in SG and it's the white pepper crab, I normally like black pepper better but the ads in this place said it's famous for white pepper crab, so that's what i go with this time. I only order the crab + beer + rice. It was ok, i like the black pepper/chili crab that i got from Jumbo better + it has A/C!Maybe I would like their chili crab or black pepper crab better! But... until next time!In the hot summer, this place has no AC and only covers to keep you away from the heat, so choose wisely if you decided to come, probably better to come at night :)

photos.caption: Photo of No Signboard Seafood Restaurant - Singapore, Singapore. White Pepper crab
Photo of No Signboard Seafood Restaurant - Singapore, Singapore. Menu Cover
Photo of No Signboard Seafood Restaurant - Singapore, Singapore

0HTs45t1S4L1trMxlDl1iA.text: The food was great but the price seemed a bit too much for what was offered. I was left paying a lot for very little and sadly I was still hungry after leaving the restaurant.Coconut in the shell juice was $5. It was pretty small and considering how coconuts are pretty much a local produce I was expecting it to be cheaper than in the US.Oddly enough they also charge for napkins and towel...seriously?? For the prices you are charging, it should be included.So we ordered Abalone, Scallops, Chilli Crab, and Shrimp.Although as mentioned the food was great, it was hard to justify the prices they were asking for.Scallops were sliced in half to give the impression that  a lot of scallops were actually served in the dish. This is the same tactic where in Viet cuisine, when you ask for meat balls in your noodle soup, they just give you one meat ball and cut it into four pieces.The Chilli crab was good but there was way too much sauce. The Shrimp sauce was pretty good they made a sweet butternut squash puree.Only come to place if you have a ton of money to fling because or else you'll be pretty hungry after realizing you didn't order enough.

photos.caption: Photo of No Signboard Seafood Restaurant - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of No Signboard Seafood Restaurant - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of No Signboard Seafood Restaurant - Singapore, Singapore

XNRJ0C1A7MNpxNFrVe7yyA.text: We originally went to Geylang to eat hokkian noodle in one of famous coffee shop, but unfortunately they were closed, So we end up went to this place. We know this is a "hot spot" for tourist and was expecting a good meal there. We were about to order the crab, but looking at its price, we turned it down. $85 for a crab its a big NO. So we order the other things, black pepper deer meat, drunken prawn, kangkong, and bamboo clam with ice tea and a barley. The good dishes were kangkoong and the clam. Other than that was disappointed us a lot. Drunken prawn was tasteless, the meat were so so, not so much flavor.  Our bill was $130++ so disappointed for the taste and price. Not worth at all.

photos.caption: Photo of No Signboard Seafood Restaurant - Singapore, Singapore

mGnpBMVmaDxIR7LSVUzkoQ.text: How should I began?Crab is lame ...Price is super unreasonable ...Nothing exciting, except for their buns ... which why would anyone come to an expensive restaurant for buns.

F-uhsegAAHm5hcoHyu-10w.text: We wanted to try the chilli crabs and came here with a large group of friends. We ordered a variety of food, all very good. Ordered 2 types of crab both very tasty. In the kitchen they have all the seafood live in water tanks as well as a cage full of frogs. Great atmosphere all outside which is covered. By the time we left, people were lining up to get in. Definitely worth visiting. If you order beer, the glasses are regularly replaced with cold ones to keep the beer cold.

OF3Icr5r1V7bWnhN94Eyzg.text: I do not recommend this place.  Very rude staffs.  Not friendly at all!  Asked for tissue, wet towels, change plates etc. all took 15-20 mins!!  Food: 3 stars Price: 1 stars VERY EXPENSIVE. $128 for crab, $28 for chicken dishDecor: 2 stars for inside, 4 stars for outside seating because of the viewService: 1 stars. Very rude. I will not come back here.  Mostly tourists from the hotel around the restaurants. Over priced and just okay food. Jumbo Seafood might be better.

3KMX04FSb62-Xc2hm9JIkw.text: I decided to check out No Signboard for my first chilli crab experience in Singapore. And my gosh, it was fantastic. Really, truly fantastic. I was super hungry, and ended up eating by myself. That being said, the smallest crab I could get was still huge. It took a bit of time to come out, but was well worth the wait - it was amazing. Juicy, moist, flavorful. Messy as heck, but worth every drip and stain.Mine was not spicy in the slightest. Later, I spoke to a local who told me it was probably because many Singaporeans assume white folks don't like spice. So, lesson learned - next time, ask for spicy, and be firm. Other than that, it was amazing.The place is not cheap, but is so worth it. I would return in a heartbeat.

photos.caption: Photo of No Signboard Seafood Restaurant - Singapore, Singapore
